M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises, or who fails to maintain essential services such as hot water, is liable for damages.

M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, §19 and M.G.L. c. 185C, §3.

M.G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, §19 and M.G.L. c. 185C, §3.

105 C.M.R. 410.190.proposition: The absence of hot water violates the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.190, which requires landlords to supply hot water of at least 110°F.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The landlord’s failure to timely remedy the condition constitutes a violation of M.G.L. c. 186, §14, notwithstanding Defendant’s asserted efforts, because the statute imposes strict liability for failure to maintain basic services. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: Blackett is a common-law constructive eviction / covenant of quiet enjoyment case and does not interpret or apply M.G.L. c. 186, §14 or describe that statute as imposing strict liability for failure to maintain basic services. The decision focuses on landlord responsibility for noise from a lounge they controlled and rejects an intent requirement by emphasizing that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling, but it does not frame this as statutory strict liability nor as a failure to remedy basic services. Therefore it does not support the specific statutory/strict-liability proposition stated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The landlord’s failure to timely remedy the condition constitutes a violation of M.G.L. c. 186, §14, notwithstanding Defendant’s asserted efforts, because the statute imposes strict liability for failure to maintain basic services. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly declines to decide whether liability under G.L. c. 186, §14 (or under the warranty of habitability) is strict for failure to maintain habitable conditions or basic services. The court instead holds only that §14 does not require malicious or intentional conduct and is satisfied, at least, by reckless interference with quiet enjoyment. Because the court leaves open whether negligence or strict liability suffices, it does not support the proposition that the statute imposes strict liability regardless of the landlord’s efforts to remedy the condition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Solomon…suggests that in the landlord-tenant context, proof of negligence should not be necessary. She argues that the warranty of habitability imposes strict liability on landlords for injuries to tenants caused by unsanitary apartment conditions… We need not decide whether a tenant could recover for purely emotional harm on a theory of negligence or strict liability, or whether the Legislature intended to authorize such recovery as ‘consequential’ damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.raw_text: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124 (1959)
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.proposition: The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment arises both from statute and common law. See Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124 (1959); Winthrop Realty Co. v. Commissioner of Corps. & Taxation, 297 Mass. 471 (1937).
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment only in common‑law terms, treating the landlord’s failure to provide essential services as a breach of that covenant and as constructive eviction. It does not mention any statute as the source of the covenant or indicate that the covenant arises from both statute and common law. Thus, while it is authority for the scope and breach of the common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment, it does not support the specific proposition that the covenant arises from both statute and common law.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.relevant_excerpt: “Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see H. W. Robinson Carpet Co. v. Fletcher, 315 Mass. 350, 353; annotation 41 A. L. R. 2d 1414, 1423, 1439) and ‘enables the lessee to recover the damages caused to him thereby and also provides the lessee with the defense of “constructive eviction” (if he removes from the premises).’”

Winthrop Realty Co. v. Commissioner of C.raw_text: Winthrop Realty Co. v. Commissioner of Corps. & Taxation, 297 Mass. 471 (1937)
Winthrop Realty Co. v. Commissioner of C.proposition: The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment arises both from statute and common law. See Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124 (1959); Winthrop Realty Co. v. Commissioner of Corps. & Taxation, 297 Mass. 471 (1937).
Winthrop Realty Co. v. Commissioner of C.support_reasoning: Winthrop Realty is an equity case about whether a defendant was a bona fide purchaser where a third party paid off her mortgage with fraudulently obtained funds. The opinion does not involve landlord–tenant law, leases, or covenants of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss the origin (statutory or common-law) of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment arises from both statute and common law.
Winthrop Realty Co. v. Commissioner of C.relevant_excerpt: No portion of the opinion discusses covenants of quiet enjoyment, implied covenants in leases, or their statutory or common-law origins; the case instead concerns equitable tracing of funds and bona fide purchaser status: "The right of the plaintiff to relief in this suit rests wholly upon the contention that the defendant was not a bona fide purchaser of the discharge of the mortgage."

Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App..raw_text: Hemingway v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 978 (1983)
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App..proposition: The violation of the sanitary code constitutes evidence of a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Hemingway v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 978 (1983).
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App..case_name: Curtin v. Board of Survey & Planning of Waltham
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App..support_reasoning: Nothing in the provided opinion involves landlord-tenant law, the sanitary code, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The case concerns subdivision rules, planning board obligations, and waiver of regulatory requirements in the context of land development, not residential habitability or quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that violation of the sanitary code constitutes evidence of a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: Sections 4 (“Design Standards”).2(“Street Design”).2(“Location and Alignment”).2(“Projections”) and 5(“Required Improvements”) ,5(“Utilities”),3(“Utility Extensions”) of the subdivision rules and regulations adopted by the defendant board (G. L. c. 41, § 81Q) must be read in conjunction with §§ 1 (“Purpose and Authority).3(“Variation”) and 2(“Procedures for the Subdivision of Land”).3(“General”).2(“Compliance with These Rules and Regulations”) of the same rules and regulations.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The landlord’s unreasonable delay in repairing or replacing essential equipment has been held to breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses when a landlord’s conduct constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, citing prior cases where failure to repair known defects can violate § 14, but this case itself does not involve delay in repairing or replacing essential equipment. Instead, the holding is that a mere statutory violation (here, the lead paint statute) without proof of at least negligence and notice is insufficient to establish a § 14 violation. The proposition about unreasonable delay in repairing essential equipment is drawn from other cases (e.g., Simon, Darmetko, Dorgan, Cruz), not from the specific facts or holding of Al‑Ziab itself, so Al‑Ziab does not directly support it.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear… there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Courts have found that lack of heat or hot water substantially interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court characterizes the lack of heat as seriously impairing the character and value of the premises and orders declaratory, injunctive, and damages relief on the quiet enjoyment claim. This directly supports the proposition that lack of heat (and by close analogy hot water) substantially interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “The tenant correctly argues that the judge erred in declaring that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil constituted a defense to the quiet enjoyment claim. A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction ordering that heat be provided…; and (c) an assessment of damages…”}```

Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Ma.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Ma.proposition: Courts have found that lack of heat or hot water substantially interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979).
Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses defects in floors and a leaky roof as breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and as interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not mention lack of heat or hot water, nor does it characterize such conditions as substantially interfering with quiet enjoyment. Thus, while it is authority that serious physical defects (like a leaking roof) can interfere with quiet enjoyment, it does not support the specific proposition about lack of heat or hot water.
Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The judge further ruled that the leaks in the roof (but not the defective floors) interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. Because of this interference, and based on his reading of G. L. c. 186, § 14, the judge ruled that the plaintiff was entitled to an additional $5,358, three times her monthly rent obligation ($47) for each month during which the leaky roof was unrepaired…”
